title: The Phone Psychology Lesson
hook: Why patients hang up after 3 rings — and what it costs you.
content:
Here's something most practice owners don't know.

A patient calling your office has already decided they want to book. They're not "shopping around." They picked YOU.

But here's the psychology:

Ring 1-2: They're patient.
Ring 3-4: They're annoyed.
Ring 5+: They assume you're closed, disorganized, or don't care.

Studies show 85% of people who hang up don't call back. They call the next name on Google.

That's not a missed call. That's a patient choosing your competitor because you were 10 seconds too slow.

The practice that answers fastest wins. Not the best dentist. Not the cheapest. The fastest.

Something to think about next time your front desk is "busy."

title: The Real Reason Patients Ghost
hook: Your patients aren't ghosting you. You're ghosting them.
content:
Practice owners always ask me: "Why do patients book and not show up?"

Here's the truth nobody talks about.

The average time between booking and appointment: 8 days.

Number of times most practices contact them in that window: Zero.

Then you're surprised when they forget? Or book somewhere else that had an earlier slot?

The practices with 95%+ show rates do three things:
1. Confirmation text within 1 hour of booking
2. Reminder 48 hours before
3. "We're excited to see you" message morning-of

That's it. Three texts. Takes 30 seconds to automate.

Your patients want to come. They just need you to make it easy to remember.

title: I Built An AI Receptionist For A Med Spa
hook: I built an AI receptionist for a med spa. Here's what happened in 30 days.
notes: WORD-FOR-WORD format copy from viral video. Proven 100k+ views format.
content:
I built an AI receptionist for a med spa. Here's what happened in 30 days.

This med spa was losing 40% of their calls to voicemail. Botox, fillers, laser treatments — gone to competitors.

So I built them an AI that:
- Answers every call in 2 seconds
- Books appointments 24/7
- Speaks English and Spanish
- Knows their entire menu and pricing

First week: 847 calls answered. Zero went to voicemail.

Week two: They noticed something weird. Appointments were booking at 11pm. At 2am. At 6am on Sunday.

Turns out 40% of their ideal clients — busy professionals — can only call outside business hours.

Month one results:
- 94% booking rate
- $11,400 in recovered revenue
- Staff focusing on patients, not phones

The owner told me: "This is like having a receptionist that never sleeps, never calls in sick, and never puts anyone on hold."

Comment 'DEMO' if you want to see how it works for your practice.

title: POV: You Just Discovered AI For Your Med Spa
hook: POV: You just discovered this AI and your med spa is about to change forever.
notes: POV format is one of most viral on TikTok. Creates immersion + curiosity.
content:
POV: You just discovered this AI and your med spa is about to change forever.

You used to miss 40% of calls because your receptionist can only answer one phone at a time.

Now? Zero calls missed. Ever.

You used to lose $300 Botox appointments to voicemail.

Now? They book at 2am while you sleep.

You used to stress about no-shows ruining your schedule.

Now? The AI follows up automatically and fills empty slots.

Your staff used to be chained to the phone all day.

Now? They actually take care of patients.

The best part? It costs less than one day of payroll per month.

This isn't the future. Med spas are using this right now.

Comment 'HOW' and I'll show you exactly how it works.

title: The Authority List
hook: As someone who's listened to 10,000+ medical office calls, these are the 3 biggest mistakes I hear.
content:
I've spent the last two years building AI phone systems for clinics. I've heard thousands of real patient calls.

Here are the 3 mistakes I hear over and over:

Mistake 1: The hold spiral.
"Please hold." Patient holds for 90 seconds. Gets transferred. Holds again. By minute 3, they've hung up and called your competitor.

Mistake 2: The voicemail black hole.
"Leave a message and we'll call you back." 70% of patients don't leave one. They just call the next name on Google.

Mistake 3: The information dump.
Patient asks one question. Receptionist gives a 2-minute speech about insurance, hours, parking, and paperwork. Patient just wanted to know if you're taking new patients.

Every one of these costs you $200+ per call.

The fix isn't hiring more people. It's designing a system where patients get answers in under 10 seconds.

Follow for more — I post stuff like this every week.

title: The Lunch Hour Problem
hook: 11:30am to 1:30pm. That's when you lose the most patients.
content:
Ran the data across 50+ medical and dental practices.

The highest call volume? 11:30am - 1:30pm.

Know what else happens then? Lunch breaks. Reduced staff. Voicemail.

This isn't a coincidence. Patients call during THEIR lunch break — the one time they're free.

And that's exactly when most practices are least available.

The math:
• Average lunch window: 25-30 calls
• Staff coverage: 50% or less
• Missed call rate: 40-60%

That's 12-18 missed patients. Every single day.

Solving lunch coverage alone could be worth $50K/year to your practice.

title: The $200 Patient Myth
hook: Stop calculating patient value wrong. Here's the real math.
content:
Everyone says "average patient value is $200" or whatever your first visit brings in.

That's the wrong number.

A patient who stays with your practice 5 years is worth:

• 2 cleanings/year × 5 years = 10 visits
• Plus X-rays, fillings, crowns, referrals

Real lifetime value: $3,000-$7,000 depending on your practice.

So when you miss a call and lose that patient to a competitor, you didn't lose $200.

You lost $5,000 and gave it to someone else.

This is why the most profitable practices obsess over first impressions. Not because one visit matters — because the relationship matters.

Every missed call is a $5,000 decision.

title: The Hiring Math Nobody Does
hook: Before you hire another receptionist, do this math.
content:
Your front desk is overwhelmed. Calls are getting missed. The obvious solution: hire another person.

Let's run the real numbers.

New receptionist:
• Salary: $35,000-$45,000/year
• Benefits: $8,000-$12,000/year
• Training: 2-3 months before they're useful
• Sick days, vacation, turnover

Total cost: $50K+ per year. And they still can't answer calls at 2am or handle 5 lines at once.

Alternative math:
• What if you could cover 100% of overflow calls for $500/month?
• That's $6,000/year
• Works 24/7, never calls in sick, handles unlimited simultaneous calls

I'm not saying don't hire. I'm saying know what problem you're actually solving.

Sometimes you need more humans for patient care. Sometimes you need technology for phone coverage.

Most practices hire for the wrong problem.

title: The Side-by-Side Test
hook: We ran your office's calls through AI for a week. Here's the before and after.
content:
Practice in Texas. 4 providers. Good reputation. Thought they were doing fine.

We tracked one week of calls:
• 312 total calls
• 67 went to voicemail
• 23 hung up before voicemail finished

90 missed opportunities. In 7 days.

Then we turned on AI backup for week two. Same call volume.

• 308 total calls
• 0 went to voicemail
• 0 hang-ups
• 94% converted to appointments

The staff wasn't working harder. They just had backup.

Revenue difference: $11,400 in one week.

If your practice does 300+ calls a week and you're not tracking this, you're guessing with your revenue.

Comment 'AUDIT' and I'll show you how to run this test yourself.

title: The 2AM Proof
hook: These 3 appointments were booked while everyone was asleep.
content:
Tuesday, 2:17am: Emergency toothache. Booked same-day 8am slot.

Thursday, 11:42pm: New patient, found you on Google, wanted to lock in an appointment before they forgot.

Sunday, 6:15am: Parent booking for kid before the school week starts.

Three appointments. $740 in revenue. Zero staff involvement.

These patients would have called someone else by morning. Instead, they're on your calendar.

This is what 24/7 coverage actually looks like. Not a voicemail. Not a "we'll call you back." An actual booking, instantly.

Your competitors' phones go to voicemail at 5pm. Yours doesn't have to.

Link in bio to see how it works.

title: The Money Question (Interactive)
hook: I'll give you 10 seconds to guess how much this practice was losing.
content:
Here's what I know:

• 4-provider dental practice
• 340 calls per week
• 18% going to voicemail
• Open 45 hours/week

How much were they losing per month?

[10-second countdown timer]

...

$26,400.

Here's the math:

• 340 calls × 18% missed = 61 missed calls/week
• 61 × 70% would've booked = 43 lost patients/week
• 43 × $150 average value = $6,450/week
• × 4 weeks = $25,800/month

They had no idea until we ran the audit.

Comment your guess. If you were within $3K, I'll send you our free calculator to run your own numbers.
